item.title: Levenshtein distance for approximate match
item.description: The problem, simply stated, is that of typoes and inconsistent spelling and pluraliziation. Let’s say you have a collection of text that you want to annotate with some metadata, like categories and tags. You don’t want to set aside ahead of time exactly which tags you want to use, but you want to catch through some test or lint step that you’ve done something wrong by typing “apples” into a field that really has “apple” most of the time.

item.title: Arborbike, a first review
item.description: Plus: fun to ride, big front basket. It's a very nice bike that you're riding, with a good 3 speed shifter and a very sturdy construction. Minus: no lights, no bell, no helmets. More specifically, I am told that the lights come on automatically, and that there is a bell somewhere, but I didn't find it and it wasn't labeled. I did have a helmet with me so I wore that.

item.title: 2015 Skywarn training
item.description: After three or four years of planning to get Skywarn training, this year I finally did it. The good folks at Washtenaw County Emergency Operations Center and at the National Weather Service in White Lake, MI did a training session at Pioneer High School. The class was concurrent with a Michigan ballroom dancing competition so there was music and festivities and accomplished looking dancers to enjoy before the class. I was there with John Hritz KD8MKE and Ann Hanson.

item.title: Kanban; or, management by post-it note
item.description: I wrote a few years back about a mini-kanban that John Hritz had put together to remember to refill washer fluid. There are a lot of colorful sticky notes around my workplace these days, so I thought I'd read up on how kanban-inspired systems are being used for process management in the software development and other non-manufacturing worlds. Some inspiring examples (with post-its to illustrate): Corey Ladas on Kanban systems for software engineering: A perfect state of flow may be very difficult, or at least uneconomical, to achieve in a robust product development process.
